intro: Brassica rapa convar. mesopotamica, commonly known as the wild mustard, is a herbaceous annual plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring alternate, lance-shaped leaves and yellow flowers arranged in racemes. The plant produces small, round pods containing several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found along roadsides, fields, and waste areas. Botanically, it is characterized by its simple, serrated leaves and its role as a wild relative of cultivated brassicas.
